articles.headline: Wal-Mart to Expand Health Plan
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart Stores, facing a raft of state bills that would require it to increase spending on employee health insurance, plans to ease several longstanding -- and heavily criticized -- restrictions on who is eligible for benefits, the company said y...
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, facing a raft of state bills that would require it to increase spending on employee health insurance, plans to ease several longstanding -- and heavily criticized -- restrictions on who is eligible for benefits, the company said yesterday.     Wal-Mart said that for the first time it would permit part-time employees to enroll their children in the health insurance plan, and it pledged to reduce significantly the waiting period before a new part-time employee is eligible for benefits, though it declined to specify the reduction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores, facing a raft of state bills that would require it to increase spending on employee health insurance, plans to ease several longstanding -- and heavily criticized -- restrictions on who is eligible for benefits, the company said yesterday.

articles.headline: Dubai Company Delays New Role at Six U.S. Ports
articles.snippet: The Dubai company at the center of a political furor over its plans to take over some terminal operations at six American ports said Thursday night that it planned to close the deal next week but that it would ''not exercise control'' over its new...
articles.abstract: The Dubai company at the center of a political furor over its plans to take over some terminal operations at six American ports said Thursday night that it planned to close the deal next week but that it would ''not exercise control'' over its new operations in the United States while the Bush administration tried to calm opposition in Congress.     The statement may provide a little time and political breathing room for President Bush, who has appeared taken by surprise at the opposition from Republicans and Democrats alike over the deal involving one of the country's few close Arab allies. But it was not clear how long the company was willing to suspend control over its new American properties or whether its offer would assuage the members of Congress, governors and mayors who have vowed to block the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 - The Dubai company at the center of a political furor over its plans to take over some terminal operations at six American ports said Thursday night that it planned to close the deal next week but that it would "not exercise control" over its new operations in the United States while the Bush administration tried to calm opposition in Congress.
articles.byline: By David S. Cloud and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Violent Cycle of Revenge Stuns Iraqis
articles.snippet: After a day of violence so raw and so personal, Iraqis woke on Thursday morning to a tense new world in which, it seemed, anything was possible.      The violence on Wednesday was the closest Iraq had come to civil war, and Iraqis were stunned. In...
articles.abstract: After a day of violence so raw and so personal, Iraqis woke on Thursday morning to a tense new world in which, it seemed, anything was possible.      The violence on Wednesday was the closest Iraq had come to civil war, and Iraqis were stunned. In Al Amin, a neighborhood in southeast Baghdad, a Shiite man said he had watched gunmen set a house on fire. It was identified as the residence of Sunni Arab militants, said the man, Abu Abbas, though no one seemed to know for sure who they were.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 23 - After a day of violence so raw and so personal, Iraqis woke on Thursday morning to a tense new world in which, it seemed, anything was possible.

articles.headline: More Clashes Shake Iraq; Political Talks Are in Ruins
articles.snippet: A groundswell of sectarian fury continued to roil Iraq on Thursday after Wednesday's bombing of a major Shiite shrine, leaving at least 138 people dead in the past two days and political negotiations over a new government in ruins.      The threat...
articles.abstract: A groundswell of sectarian fury continued to roil Iraq on Thursday after Wednesday's bombing of a major Shiite shrine, leaving at least 138 people dead in the past two days and political negotiations over a new government in ruins.      The threat of full-scale civil war loomed over the country as Sunni politicians lashed out at Shiite leaders on Thursday, accusing them of igniting anti-Sunni reprisals, and at the American military, charging it with standing idly by as the violence erupted. The most powerful Sunni Arab political group said it was suspending talks with Shiite and Kurdish politicians on forming a new government.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 23 - A groundswell of sectarian fury continued to roil Iraq on Thursday after Wednesday's bombing of a major Shiite shrine, leaving at least 138 people dead in the past two days and political negotiations over a new government in ruins.

articles.headline: Increasingly, the Home Is Paying for Retirement
articles.snippet: Two years ago, George and Mollie Weiner were scraping by on $1,800 a month in Social Security payments and just $100 in monthly payouts from their individual retirement accounts.      But last year, the couple, both 80, realized they could generat...
articles.abstract: Two years ago, George and Mollie Weiner were scraping by on $1,800 a month in Social Security payments and just $100 in monthly payouts from their individual retirement accounts.      But last year, the couple, both 80, realized they could generate more income from their two-bedroom condo near Tampa, Fla., which had more than doubled in value since they bought it in 1997. They took out a ''reverse mortgage,'' a loan that does not require monthly repayments, giving them access to more than $100,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, George and Mollie Weiner were scraping by on $1,800 a month in Social Security payments and just $100 in monthly payouts from their individual retirement accounts.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Eduardo Porter

articles.headline: Born Together, Raised Together, So Why Not in Classroom, Too?
articles.snippet: When Kathy Dolan, a mother in Queens, sent her twin boys off to kindergarten, she had one wish: that they face the new hurdles of numbers and alphabets in the same class. With her own parents seriously ill, and her sons close to them, ''the boys h...
articles.abstract: When Kathy Dolan, a mother in Queens, sent her twin boys off to kindergarten, she had one wish: that they face the new hurdles of numbers and alphabets in the same class. With her own parents seriously ill, and her sons close to them, ''the boys had enough chaos and turmoil in their life,'' Ms. Dolan said, ''without being separated.''     Her request was denied, she said, until she produced a note from the boys' pediatrician recommending that they be kept together. She faced the same resistance, though, when they entered first grade last September.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kathy Dolan, a mother in Queens, sent her twin boys off to kindergarten, she had one wish: that they face the new hurdles of numbers and alphabets in the same class. With her own parents seriously ill, and her sons close to them, "the boys had enough chaos and turmoil in their life," Ms. Dolan said, "without being separated."

articles.headline: Auditor's Links Did Not Stop This Fraud
articles.snippet: JUST how independent should auditors be from their clients? Should they only do audits, or is it acceptable for them to perform other services for the audit clients or for related companies?     Those are issues that have divided auditors from reg...
articles.abstract: JUST how independent should auditors be from their clients? Should they only do audits, or is it acceptable for them to perform other services for the audit clients or for related companies?     Those are issues that have divided auditors from regulators for years. Auditors in the United States lost some, but not nearly all, of their other activities under the Sarbanes-Oxley law passed in 2002 in response to the Enron fraud, but that reflected their decreased political influence more than it did a careful analysis of real-world results.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST how independent should auditors be from their clients? Should they only do audits, or is it acceptable for them to perform other services for the audit clients or for related companies?

articles.headline: A Ship Already Sailed
articles.snippet: In the outcry over who should run America's seaport terminals, one clear trend appears to have been overlooked: American companies began withdrawing decades ago from the unglamorous business of stevedoring, ceding the now-booming industry to enter...
articles.abstract: In the outcry over who should run America's seaport terminals, one clear trend appears to have been overlooked: American companies began withdrawing decades ago from the unglamorous business of stevedoring, ceding the now-booming industry to enterprises in Asia and the Middle East.      So it is no accident that American companies are not in the top ranks of global terminal operators, who have ridden the coattails of the explosion in world trade. That shift has transferred growing financial clout to a handful of seafaring centers in Hong Kong, Singapore and now the emirate of Dubai.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Feb. 23 - In the outcry over who should run America's seaport terminals, one clear trend appears to have been overlooked: American companies began withdrawing decades ago from the unglamorous business of stevedoring, ceding the now-booming industry to enterprises in Asia and the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: After Hurricanes Come Tempests Over Cleanups
articles.snippet: When a big contracting company hired him to clean up this small town northwest of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, Matthew Lopez saw it as a way to help his neighbors and to make decent money: $9 for every cubic yard of hurricane debris he del...
articles.abstract: When a big contracting company hired him to clean up this small town northwest of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, Matthew Lopez saw it as a way to help his neighbors and to make decent money: $9 for every cubic yard of hurricane debris he delivered to a dump.     But as soon as he started clearing downed branches, there was a problem: out-of-town contractors that also worked for the larger company were sneaking into his territory and snatching up the loose debris.
articles.lead_paragraph: PONCHATOULA, La. - When a big contracting company hired him to clean up this small town northwest of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, Matthew Lopez saw it as a way to help his neighbors and to make decent money: $9 for every cubic yard of hurricane debris he delivered to a dump.

articles.headline: Loan Buyer Accounting Is Faulted
articles.snippet: An internal investigation has uncovered new evidence that senior executives of Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of American home mortgages, manipulated its accounting in the 1990's to meet earnings projections so that top executives could receive mor...
articles.abstract: An internal investigation has uncovered new evidence that senior executives of Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of American home mortgages, manipulated its accounting in the 1990's to meet earnings projections so that top executives could receive more than $27 million in bonuses.      In a 616-page report that was released Thursday, former Senator Warren Rudman and a team of lawyers and investigators concluded after an 18-month review that Fannie Mae's accounting practices ''in virtually all of the areas that we reviewed were not consistent with'' generally accepted accounting principles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 - An internal investigation has uncovered new evidence that senior executives of Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of American home mortgages, manipulated its accounting in the 1990's to meet earnings projections so that top executives could receive more than $27 million in bonuses.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Eric Dash
